etymologies: mid 19th century; earliest use found in Peter Simmonds (1814–1897), newsagent and journalist. Partly from Malayalam pāla and its cognate Telugu pāla, and partly from Tamil pālai (usually also pronounced as pāla), name applied to several plants with milky sap, respectively from Malayalam pāl and Tamil pāl animal or vegetable milk

definitions: A small Indian tree, Wrightia tinctoria (family Apocynaceae), with white wood and a milky sap.

notes.text: "pala indigo" noun a kind of indigo obtained from the leaves of this tree.

etymologies: mid 19th century. From post-classical Latin pala shovel-shaped or scoop-shaped structure forming an extension of the tarsus of the foreleg in certain aquatic heteropteran insects from classical Latin pāla spade, of uncertain origin

definitions: A shovel-shaped or scoop-shaped structure; specifically one forming an extension of the tarsus of the foreleg in certain aquatic heteropteran insects, used chiefly in feeding and (by the male) in mating.
